questions.text: A young man develops slurred speech and an unsteady staggering gait after drinking heavily at a party. What could be his blood alcohol level?
questions.solution:
The alcohol level in a patient with slurred speech and staggering gait would approximately be 150-200 mg/100 mL.

The behavioral changes with respect to the amount of alcohol in the blood are as follows :

  • >30 mg/100 mL causes impairment of driving skills.
  • 30 - 50 mg/100 mL leads to definite deterioration of driving ability.
  • 50 - 100 mg/100 mL starts showing objective signs such as loud rambunctious talking and laughing, progressive loss of social inhibitions, and some sensory disturbance.
  • 100 - 150 mg/100 mL causes ataxia, impaired memory, sleepiness, and slowed reaction time.
  • 150 - 200 mg/100 mL leads to obvious drunkenness, staggering gait, and nausea.
  • 200 - 300 mg/100 mL causes stupor, vomiting, and maybe even lead to coma.
  • 300 - 350 mg/100 mL can lead to stupor/ coma with a risk of aspiration of vomit.
  • >350 mg/100 mL can cause respiratory center paralysis leading to death.

Acute alcohol intoxication can be treated with the evacuation of stomach and bowel contents and gastric lavage with an alkaline solution. 1L of normal saline with 10% glucose, 100 mg thiamine, and 15U insulin may be useful. If the coma progresses deeper, stimulants like strychnine and caffeine can be used. Patients should be started on artificial respiration if there is respiratory depression or difficulty breathing.¬†

Chronic alcohol intoxication can be treated with disulfiram (daily dose of 250 mg OD), conditioned reflex treatment, hypnosis, and psychotherapy.

The alcohol content in common alcoholic drinks :

  • Rum, liquor - 50-60%.
  • Whisky, vodka, gin, brandy - 40-45%.
  • Port, sherry - 20%.
  • Wine, champagne - 10-15%.
  • Beer - 4-8%

According to the Motor Vehicles (Amendment) Act 2019, whoever while driving, or attempting to drive, a motor vehicle, has, in his blood, alcohol exceeding 30 mg/100 mL of blood, detected in a test by a breath analyzer is punishable by law.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman presented with fatigue and unrelenting severe bone discomfort. She currently resides in an old age home and has minimal exposure to sunlight. Investigations revealed low levels of vitamin D and elevated levels of PTH and ALP. A radiograph of the hip is given. What is the diagnosis?

PTH : Parathormone
ALP : Alkaline phosphatase
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the x-ray showing Looser zones are suggestive of osteomalacia.

In osteomalacia, the osteoid matrix is secreted at a normal rate but the mineralization is decreased i.e, decreased mineral apposition rate and increased osteoid maturation time. Osteomalacia mainly presents with extreme fatigue and weakness along with the chance of fractures.

Lab findings reveal normal/low calcium and elevated alkaline phosphatase. 

Looser zones are the classical lesions of osteomalacia. These are due to incomplete stress fractures which heal with callus-lacking in calcium. They are thin transverse bands of rarefaction especially seen in the pelvis, the shaft of long bones such as the femur neck, and the axillary edge of the scapula.

Treatment options include calcium and vitamin D supplements along with phosphate supplements.

The image below shows Looser's zone:

 

Codfish vertebrae are the biconcave vertebral bodies seen in osteomalacia. They are seen in:

  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Osteomalacia
  • Osteoporosis

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the hospital after accidentally finding a painless lump in her right breast. The lump is solitary and is located below the areola. She also recalls a blood-stained discharge from her nipple a few days back. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a solitary intraductal papilloma.¬†¬†

Intraductal papilloma¬†is a¬†benign, proliferative breast disorder without atypia. It can be solitary or multiple (papillomatosis). Most commonly seen in premenopausal women.¬†It is associated with¬†blood-stained¬†discharge and cystic swelling beneath the areola.

It is important to rule out the possibility of carcinoma with blood tests and cytology. If atypia is present,¬†excision is the treatment of choice.

Other options:

Option A:¬†Duct ectasia is the dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts and is associated with periductal mastitis.¬†The dilated ducts get filled with stagnant brown or¬†green-coloured secretions and get discharged from the¬†nipple. Later, it can form an indurated mass that resembles a carcinoma and should be carefully ruled out. Fibrosis causes a slit-like retraction of the nipple. The definitive treatment is Hadfield's operation which involves the excision of all major ducts. Duct ectasia is mainly seen in perimenopausal women (45-55 years of age).

Option B:¬†Fibroadenoma is¬†a benign breast tumour that is usually firm, rubbery, and mobile. They occur in women in their 20s and 30s, and they are frequently multiple and bilateral. It has no increased risk of developing into malignancy.¬†

Option D:¬†Paget‚Äôs disease is the skin manifestation of underlying breast carcinoma. It is characterised by¬†nipple erythema¬†and irritation. It is associated with¬†pruritus¬†and may progress to crusting and ulceration. The discharge is from the surface of the skin and not from the nipple. It can be differentiated from eczema by biopsy. Features that indicate eczema include bilateral nipple involvement, younger females, and signs of eczema in other parts.

Related Pearl: Discharge from the Nipple

questions.text: An elderly man is admitted with deep vein thrombosis in his left leg. He is a known case of hypertension and chronic kidney disease (creatinine clearance - 29 mL/min). Which of the following will you prescribe for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Unfractionated heparin is to be prescribed to manage this patient's condition. Heparin is cleared and degraded primarily by the reticuloendothelial system and only a tiny amount appears in the urine. Hence, it is safe to be used in patients with renal impairment/ chronic kidney disease.

Heparin, low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), and fondaparinux have no intrinsic anticoagulant activity. These agents accelerate the action of¬†anti-thrombin. Heparin binds to anti-thrombin and brings about a conformational change in anti-thrombin that accelerates the inhibition of factor Xa (anti-thrombin inhibits activated coagulation factors, especially thrombin and factor Xa).

Heparin, LMWH, and fondaparinux - can be used in the initial management of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism, unstable angina, and in acute myocardial infarction.

Heparin and LMWH are used in¬†select patients with disseminated intravascular coagulation¬†and¬†coronary balloon angioplasty with or without stent placement to prevent thrombosis. Fondaparinux is contraindicated due to the risk of catheter thrombosis.

Heparin is the agent of choice for cardiopulmonary bypass surgeries.

Heparin, LMWH, and fondaparinux do not cross the placenta and hence are safe to use in pregnancy. The drugs may be discontinued 24 hours before delivery to minimize postpartum hemorrhage.

Other options :

Options B & C:¬†Low molecular weight heparin and fondaparinux are both smaller molecules and are cleared almost exclusively by kidneys. These drugs can accumulate in patients with renal impairment and lead to bleeding. Both these drugs are contraindicated in patients whose creatinine clearance is below 30 mL/min.¬†

Option D: Rivaroxaban toxicity is increased in patients with renal impairment or severe hepatic dysfunction and should be avoided in these patients.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient presents to the ENT outpatient department with decreased hearing in both ears, often associated with a ringing sensation for the past few years. The Rinne test was negative and the Schwartze sign is seen on otoscopy. Which of the following types of curves will be seen on her impedance audiometry?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of otosclerosis. As type of curve will be seen on her impedance audiometry. Decreased hearing with ringing sensation, a negative Rinne, and the presence of Schwartze sign indicate a diagnosis of otosclerosis.

Impedance audiometry is an objective test that consists of tympanometry and assessment of acoustic reflexes.  

It is based on the principle that when sound strikes against the tympanic membrane, some of it is absorbed while the rest is reflected. The reflected sound is measured to assess the compliance of the tympanic membrane. The compliance of the membrane is inverse to the intensity of the sound reflected, i.e. lesser the compliance, the more the sound reflected.

There are 5 types of tympanograms based on the change in pressures applied:

  • A- Normal tympanogram. It is seen in normal individuals. 
  • As- Low compliance in normal pressure. Seen in conditions where ossicles are fixed like in otosclerosis or malleus fixation.
  • AD- High compliance under normal pressure. Seen in conditions of ossicular discontinuity or thin tympanic membrane.
  • B-  A flat/ dome-shaped tympanogram indicates that there is no change in compliance with changes in pressure. Seen in thick tympanic membrane or fluid in the middle ear.
  • C- Compliance is increased with negative pressure in excess of 100 mmH2O. Seen in eustachian tube obstruction and retracted tympanic membrane.

Uses of impedance audiometry include testing hearing in children and infants.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: Which of the following statements about T-cells are false?

choices.text: Kill extracellular bacteria by granzymes and perforin
Œ≥Œ¥ TCR recognize peptide antigens presented by MHC molecules
Lymphocyte recirculation is seen in T lymphocytes
Normally, about 60% of mature T cells are CD4+

questions.solution:
The false statement is that γδ TCR recognizes peptide antigens presented by MHC molecules. 

γδ TCR recognizes different type of antigens without the requirement of major histocompatibility complex (MHC), whereas the αβ TCR recognize peptide antigens that are presented by MHC molecules.

T-lymphocytes develop from the thymus. They constitute around 60–70% of peripheral blood lymphocytes. T cells contain antigen-specific TCRs by which they recognize specific antigens. Each TCR is linked to six polypeptide chains, which form the CD3 complex, and the ζ chain dimer, which is involved in signal transduction.

Apart from CD3 and ζ proteins, T cells express several other proteins such as CD4, CD8, CD28, and integrins. Normally, around 60% are CD4+, and about 30% are CD8+ (hence present in a ratio of 2:1).

T-lymphocytes recirculate between tissues and home to various sites. Naive T cells circulate to the secondary lymphoid organs containing antigens where immune responses are initiated, and effector lymphocytes migrate to areas of inflammation to eliminate microbes.

The functions of γùõø T-cells:

  • Provide protection against mycobacteria by direct killing of infected macrophages
  • Kills extracellular bacteria by granzymes and perforin
  • It plays a role in maintaining self-tolerance

questions.text: A 60-year-old man suffered from acute chest pain, sweating, lightheadedness, and nausea 1 day back. Laboratory reports revealed raised cardiac troponin. ECG was suggestive of myocardial infarction. Which of the following isoenzymes of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is likely to be raised?
questions.solution:
This patient had an episode of myocardial infarction one day back. Therefore, LDH-1 is likely to be raised in this case of myocardial infarction.

Normally LDH-2 (H3M1) concentration in blood is greater than LDH-1 (H4), but this pattern is reversed in myocardial infarction; this is called the flipped pattern.

LDH enzyme is a tetramer with 4 subunits. But the subunit may be either H (heart) or M (muscle) polypeptide chains.

An increase in total LDH level is seen in hemolytic anemias, hepatocellular damage, muscular dystrophy, carcinomas, leukemias, and any condition which causes necrosis of body cells. Since total LDH is increased in many conditions, the study of iso-enzymes of LDH is of great importance.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman was brought to the casualty with a high fever and abdominal pain for the past 2 days. She has a history of inflammatory bowel disease. Her abdominal x-ray is shown below. Identify the true statement regarding this condition.

choices.text: It is defined as the dilatation of the transverse colon, with a diameter of  >6 cm
Emergency colectomy is the only treatment  in patients
Occurs as a complication of Crohn's disease
90% patients will resolve with conservative management

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the radiograph are suggestive of toxic megacolon. The true statement is that toxic megacolon is defined as the dilatation of the transverse colon to a diameter of more than 6 cm. It is usually associated with severe ulcerative colitis. It can be triggered by electrolyte imbalance and narcotics as they interfere with gut motility. 

Toxic megacolon may present with fever, abdominal pain, and abdominal distension. Bacterial infection with features of sepsis may also be seen. It can result in perforation. 

Abdominal radiography shows transverse or right colonic dilation of >6 cm and loss of haustrations.

It usually resolves with supportive treatment (correcting electrolyte imbalance, fluids, bowel rest) and medical therapy which includes glucocorticoids, anti-inflammatory drugs, and antibiotics. However, an urgent colectomy is indicated in patients who do not show signs of improvement.

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease resulting in superficial erosions confined to the mucosa and submucosa of the colon. It starts from the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous manner.

The clinical features include abdominal pain, diarrhea, rectal bleeding, tenesmus, and passage of mucus. Other symptoms include anorexia, nausea, vomiting, fever, and weight loss.

Investigations show elevated C-reactive protein, platelet count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, fecal calprotectin, and fecal lactoferrin. A colonoscopy reveals loss of typical vascular pattern, erythema, friability, and ulcerations. 

Extraintestinal manifestations associated with IBD include ocular features (episcleritis, and uveitis), dermatological manifestations (erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum), rheumatological (arthropathies, sacroiliitis, ankylosing spondylitis) and primary sclerosing cholangitis.

questions.text: A female patient with twin pregnancies underwent an abdominal ultrasound. It showed that the upper part of the body of one fetus was absent and the other fetus was normal. The echo of the normal fetus was suggestive of congestive cardiac failure. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis here is twin reversed arterial perfusion (TRAP).

TRAP is a complication seen in monochorionic multifetal gestation. It is caused by a large artery-to-artery or vein-to-vein placental shunt. Here, the recipient twin lacks a cardiac system, while the donor twin does the work of supplying blood for both twins. Blood from the donor twin reaches the iliac vessels of the recipient twin through the umbilical arteries. Therefore, in the recipient twin, only the lower body is developed, while the upper body is poorly developed. The donor twin may show signs of heart failure.

Developmental abnormality in the recipient twin:

  • No identifiable structures - Acardius amorphous
  • Failure of head growth - Acardius acephalus
  • Partially developed head with identifiable limbs - Acardius myelacephalus

Other options:¬†

Option A-¬†Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)¬†is a deep¬†arteriovenous anastomotic complication seen in¬†monochorionic¬†twins. Deoxygenated blood from the donor enters through anastomosis into a shared cotyledon for oxygen exchange. After oxygenation, the blood is taken up by the¬†recipient twin. The donor twin will have anemia and appears pale, while the recipient twin will have polycythemia and features of heart failure.

Option B-¬†Twin anemia‚Äìpolycythemia sequence (TAPS) is similar to TTTS, where the donor twin is pale and anemic, whereas the recipient twin is polycythemic. However, unlike the case with TTTS, the amniotic fluid volumes in TAPS are similar for both fetuses.

Option D-¬†Twin oligohydramnios polyhydramnios syndrome (TOPS) is seen in TTTS.¬†The donor fetus becomes oliguric due to hypovolemia, and the recipient fetus develops increased urine output due to hypervolemia. This results in oligohydramnios in the donor and hydramnios in the recipient fetus.

Related Pearl: Twinning

questions.text: A patient undergoing surgery is being maintained on anesthesia. During the procedure, he suddenly developed hyperthermia and muscle rigidity. The capnography finding is shown below. Which of the following drugs is most likely implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the capnography finding showing a progressive rise of CO2 is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia. The drug most likely implicated in this condition is succinylcholine.

Succinylcholine is a peripherally acting depolarizing muscle relaxant, commonly administered during the induction of anesthesia. It is used to relax muscles of the jaw, neck, and airway and thereby facilitate laryngoscopy and endotracheal intubation.

Malignant hyperthermia is a condition in which the patient develops sustained muscle contraction and hyperthermia. It occurs following the administration of succinylcholine and other inhaled anesthetics like halothane, isoflurane, sevoflurane, desflurane, etc. It is due to the mutation of the gene for the ryanodine receptor (Ryr 1), located on chromosome 19.

Normally, Ryr 1 is an ion channel responsible for calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. The mutated Ryr 1 leads to a sudden release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum of the skeletal muscle. This increase in intracellular calcium removes the inhibition of troponin, resulting in uncontrolled muscle contraction, which in turn, leads to an increase in adenosine triphosphatase (ATPase) activity.

This causes an uncontrolled hypermetabolic state with increased oxygen consumption and CO2 production, producing severe lactic acidosis and hyperthermia.

Dantrolene therapy is the treatment of choice.

The image given below shows capnography findings seen in malignant hyperthermia.

Other options:

D-curare, cis-atracurium, and rocuronium are non-depolarizing muscle relaxants and are not implicated in malignant hyperthermia.

Related Pearl: Malignant hyperthermia key features

Pathophysiology:

  • Prolonged opening of functionally altered ryanodine receptors, leading to uncontrolled release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction.

Drugs known to trigger malignant hyperthermia:

  • Inhaled anesthetics: Halothane, Isoflurane, Sevoflurane, Desflurane, Ether, Methoxyflurane
  • Depolarising muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine

Clinical signs:

  • Increased metabolism: Increased EtCO2, decreased SpO2, metabolic acidosis
  • Increased sympathetic activity: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrythmia
  • Muscle damage: Masseter spasm, generalised rigidity, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria
  • Hyperthermia: Fever, sweating

 Treatment: 

  • Discontinuation of all anesthetic agents
  • Hyperventilation with 100% O2
  • Dantrolene: 2.5 mg/kg intravenously every 5 min until the episode is terminated (upper limit - 10 mg/kg).
  • Correction of acid-base, electrolyte abnormality 
  • Cooling the patient

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room with a suspected opioid overdose. On examination, he had severe respiratory depression. He was intubated and started on mechanical ventilation. What is the drug of choice to be administered to this patient?
questions.solution:
Intravenous naloxone is the drug of choice in acute opioid overdose.

Naloxone is a pure opioid antagonist that reverses all effects of an opioid overdose except sedation. The first step is to ensure an adequate airway. Intubation and mechanical ventilation may be necessary.

Clinically, patients with opioid overdose present with respiratory depression¬†and pinpoint pupils (miosis). On examination, there is hypotension, bradycardia, shallow breathing, and hypothermia.

Intravenous naloxone is administered at a slow rate. Increased respiratory rate and pupillary dilation should occur promptly, which indicates signs of improvement. If there is no response to the initial dosage, repeat the dose after a few minutes. Repeated administration may be required to prevent the recurrence of opioid toxicity because naloxone has a low duration of action.

The FDA approved a higher dose of naloxone hydrochloride nasal spray to treat opioid overdose. The newly approved product delivers 8 mg of naloxone into the nasal cavity. The FDA had previously approved 2 mg and 4 mg naloxone nasal spray products.

Note: Naloxone is contraindicated in infants born to mothers with opiate addiction as it may precipitate acute neonatal withdrawal with seizures.

Other options:

Option B: Flumazenil¬†is the inverse agonist of benzodiazepine receptors and is used for the treatment of¬†benzodiazepine¬†overdose.

Option C: Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist. It is used as an analgesic for chronic pain conditions like cancer pain and also used for the treatment of opioid dependence as an alternative to methadone.

Option D: Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist that blocks opioid effects, particularly euphoria, and discourages per¬≠sons with opioid dependence from substance-seeking behaviour. It is not the first choice in acute opioid overdose.

Related Pearl: Pure opioid antagonists

Naloxone: short-acting opioid antagonist with duration of action of 1-2 hours. Used in opioid overdose and respiratory depression in newborns due to perinatal opioid use.

Naltrexone: long-acting opioid antagonist with effects lasting till 48 hours. Used for prevention of relapse in opioid addiction treatment. It is associated with hepatotoxicity. It does not suppress craving in opioid addiction but suppresses craving in chronic alcoholics.

Nalmefene: long-acting opioid antagonist with a half-life of 8-10 hours administered intravenously. Used in opioid overdose like naloxone.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of the lesion shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the lesion is a neuropathic ulcer.

A neuropathic ulcer is one that occurs due to peripheral neuropathy. In peripheral neuropathy, lack of sensation over the pressure points leads to cumulative microtrauma, minor wounds, or cuts that go unnoticed eventually developing into ulcers. They are painless, punched out with regular margins, on the plantar surface of the foot, and show the presence of calluses. 

Management of neuropathic ulcer: Debridement of all necrotic or hyperkeratotic wound tissue, proper cultures to be done if an infection is suspected for microbiological analysis. Any ulcerations subjected to sustained pressure should be subjected to pressure reduction by mechanical offloading which includes wedge shoes, total contact cast, cast walkers, etc.

Type of Ulcer Ischaemic/ Arterial Venous Neuropathic Tuberculous  
Underlying condition

Peripheral vascular disease- atherosclerosis, thromboangiitis obliterans, cervical rib, Raynaud's phenomenon

 Varicose veins, previous deep vein thrombosis Diabetes, peripheral neuropathy Tuberculosis lymph nodes, cold abscess from bone and joint tuberculosis
Location Toes, feet, legs, or even upper limb digits. The lower limb, commonly on the medial side of the ankle, is never above the middle third of the leg The plantar surface of the foot, toes Neck, axilla, and groin, tip or anterior 2/3rd of the tongue.
Characteristics

Deep, penetrating the fascia exposes the tendons, muscles, and underlying bone.

The ulcer is painful, with irregular margin tenderness, and hyperesthetic. 

 Vertically oval, and painless, the floor may have pale to no granulation tissue, induration, and tenderness at the base. painless, punched-out with regular calloused margins. 

Edges are thin, reddish blue, and undermined with pale granulation tissue, scanty discharge on the floor, and slight induration at the base.
Other features Features of ischemia in adjacent areas, like pallor, dry skin, brittle nails, loss of hair Inguinal lymph nodes enlarged, usually the vertical group, the ulcer is recurrent, forms again after healing

Dry, warm foot

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital with complaints of blurring of vision. His blood pressure is found to be 210/180 mmHg. Fundoscopic examination of the right and left eye is shown in the following image. What is the grade according to Keith, Wagner, and Barker's grading?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is grade 4 hypertensive retinopathy since the fundoscopic examination of the patient shows bilateral optic disc swelling and macular stars.

Hypertensive retinopathy refers to changes in the retinal vasculature due to systemic hypertension. The fundus changes can be classified as benign and malignant retinopathy.

Patients with benign retinopathy are usually asymptomatic. The fundoscopic changes include generalized or focal arterial narrowing, arteriovenous nicking, arteriolar reflex changes, superficial retinal hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and hard exudates. Malignant hypertensive retinopathy includes retinopathy, choroidopathy, and optic neuropathies. 

Keith-Wagener-Barker (KWB) grading of hypertensive retinopathy is commonly used to grade the severity.

Grade 1 involves mild to moderate narrowing of smaller arteries.

Grade 2 involves marked arteriolar narrowing. At the site where arteries and veins cross each other, there is a marked deflection of veins. This is known as Salus' sign.

Grade 3 includes grade 2 changes along with retinal hemorrhages, hard exudates, and cotton wool spots. Apart from this the Bonnet sign, Gunn sign, Salus' sign, and copper wiring of arterioles can also be seen.

  • Hard exudates are lipid deposits in the outer plexiform layer of the retina from leaky capillaries. They are yellow waxy spots with sharp margins, which are arranged as macular-fan or macular-star.
  • Cotton wool spots are the fluffy white lesions on the retina occurring due to ischemia and infarction.
  • Bonnet sign refers to the banking of veins at the crossing of arteries and veins.
  • Gunn sign refers to the tapering of veins on both sides of the crossing.
  • Arteriolar reflex changes indicate the light reflex changes in the retinal vasculature. Normal reflex is when the arteriole appears bright, thin, and linear. Copper wiring is when it becomes a reddish-brown reflex due to sclerosis of the arterioles. Siver wiring is when it becomes an opaque-white reflex due to continued sclerosis and is seen in grade 4 retinopathy.

Grade 4 includes grade 3 changes along with optic disc swelling and silver wiring. This is a marker of malignant hypertension.

questions.text: A clinical trial is being done for a new drug for the treatment of migraine. The p-value was found to be 0.02. Which of the following is a correct statement?

choices.text: Trial is statistically insignificant and the null hypothesis is true
Trial is statistically insignificant but the null hypothesis is false
Trial is statistically significant and the null hypothesis is false
Trial is statistically significant and the null hypothesis is true

questions.solution:
The correct statement is the trial is statistically significant and the null hypothesis is false.¬†

In the given scenario, the p-value is 0.02 which is <0.05. This means that the possibility of an association between the new drug and pain relief purely by chance is only 2%. Hence, the null hypothesis is rejected.¬†

The possibility of pain relief due to the new drug is 98%. This is the alternate hypothesis.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: A farmer developed an ulcer with central black eschar over the forearm after handling a carcass in his field. Microscopy of the specimen received from the eschar showed the following picture. Which of the following statements is correct about the laboratory features of this organism?

choices.text: Fried egg appearance on culture medium

questions.solution:
The clinical feature of developing an eschar and the image showing gram-positive bacilli is diagnostic of Bacillus anthracis. The correct statement regarding the laboratory feature of this organism is the bamboo stick appearance on microscopy.

Important laboratory features of this organism are:

  • Microscopy of the smears shows bacilli arranged end to end in the form of long chains. This is called bamboo stick appearance.
  • M'Fadyean reaction- when these bacilli are stained with polychrome methylene blue, purplish capsules can be visualized around the bacilli.
  • Medusa head appearance on agar plates- The colonies appear as locks of matted hair.
  • Inverted fir tree appearance on gelatin stab culture
  • Frosted glass appearance on the agar plate

Bacillus anthracis is a gram-positive organism and also a category A Bioterrorism agent.

Human anthrax presents in one of three ways:

  • Cutaneous anthrax (Hide porter’s disease)- Black eschar at the site of entry.
  • Pulmonary anthrax (Wool sorter’s disease)- Occurs due to the inhalation of spores from infected wool. It leads to hemorrhagic pneumonia.
  • Intestinal anthrax- Hemorrhagic diarrhea. It occurs mainly in primitive communities that eat the carcasses of animals dying of anthrax.

Robert Koch validated the Koch'spostulates after discovering the anthrax bacillus as the cause of anthrax. He also discovered the causative agents of tuberculosis and cholera. Hence, he is known as the Father of Bacteriology.

Koch's postulates, which link specific microorganisms to specific diseases, state that the microorganism must be:

  1. Found in abundance in lesions associated with disease, but not in healthy organisms
  2. Isolated from a diseased organism and able to be grown in pure culture
  3. Able to cause disease when inoculated into a healthy organism
  4. Able to re-isolate the organism from pure cultures obtained from the lesions from experimental animals

Other options:

Option A- Fried egg appearance is seen in Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

Option B- Sunray appearance is seen in microscopy of Actinomyces.

Option D- Safety pin appearance is seen on microscopy of Yersinia species, Burkholderia pseudomallei.

questions.text: A young adolescent male with a recurrent history of suppurative otitis media was brought to the hospital with high fever and chills, altered sensorium, and neck rigidity. Which part of the image given below should have been deficient for the patient to develop the current symptoms?
questions.solution:
The tegmen tympani¬†(Marked as 2 in the image), which forms the roof of the middle ear cavity, should have been deficient for the patient to develop meningitis from suppurative otitis media.

Tegmen tympani¬†separates the tympanic cavity from the¬†middle cranial fossa. It also extends posteriorly to form the roof of the aditus and antrum as¬†tegmen mastoidea. Any deficit in the tegmen tympani can facilitate the spread of middle ear infection to the middle cranial fossa.

The middle ear has a¬†roof, floor, and four walls: anterior, posterior, medial & lateral.

  • Roof: Formed by¬†tegmen tympani¬†bone
  • Floor: Formed by a thin plate of bone
  • Anterior¬†wall: Structures related are
    • Eustachian tube¬†(option¬†C)
    • Canal of tensor tympani¬†(option D)
    • Internal carotid artery
  • Posterior wall¬†(option A): It has a bony projection called a pyramid. The aditus connecting the middle ear to the attic is above the pyramid. The posterior¬†sinus,¬†also known as the¬†facial recess,¬†is a depression in the posterior wall lateral to the pyramid. It is bounded medially by the vertical part of the¬†facial nerve (VIIth nerve), laterally by the chorda tympani, and above, by the fossa incudis. Intact canal wall techniques use this for middle ear access.
  • Medial wall: It is formed by a labyrinth, and it presents as a bulge called promontory. The medial wall is related to:
    • Oval window
    • Round window
    • Processus cochleoriformis
    • Horizontal semicircular canal
    • Canal of the facial nerve
  • Lateral wall: It is mainly formed by the tympanic membrane and also by the bony outer attic wall called¬†scutum.

questions.text: A neonate was born at 42 weeks of gestation by spontaneous vaginal delivery, following signs of severe fetal distress. Greenish amniotic fluid was noted during delivery. Immediately following delivery, the baby was shifted to the NICU and had to be intubated. Her chest x-ray is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is meconium aspiration syndrome. The image shows patchy infiltrates and coarse streaking, which is a radiograph finding in infants with this condition.

Meconium aspiration syndrome occurs in some term and post-term infants. The aspirated meconium may block smaller airways leading to tachypnea, grunting, and cyanosis. The chest radiograph shows patchy infiltrates, coarse streaking of lung fields, increased anteroposterior diameter and flattening of the diaphragm. It commonly resolves within 72 hours, while a few babies may require assisted ventilation.

Other options:

Option A - Respiratory distress syndrome is also known as hyaline membrane disease. It occurs due to the decreased production and secretion of the lung surfactant. It is seen mainly in preterm babies. The radiograph will show the presence of low lung volumes, a diffuse reticular granularity of the parenchyma (ground-glass appearance), and air bronchograms.

Option B - Transient tachypnea of newborn is a self-limiting disorder occurring due to delayed clearance of lung fluid. Chest radiograph will reveal prominent perihilar pulmonary vascular markings and fluid in the intralobar fissures. It is more common in twin gestation, maternal asthma, precipitous delivery, and cesarean delivery without labor.

Option C - Congenital diaphragmatic hernia occurs due to the defective development of the diaphragm. The majority are Bochdalek hernia on the left side. Imaging may show pulmonary hypoplasia, mediastinal shift, presence of a gastric bubble, or a liver in the thoracic cavity.

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • Mediastinal shift
  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Low lung volume
  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: An elderly man presents with fatigue, chest pain, and exertional breathlessness. On auscultation, an ejection systolic murmur that radiates to the carotids was found. The murmur intensified on squatting. Which of the following will be the character of the pulse in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical scenario is suggestive of¬†aortic stenosis (AS) which has the characteristic pulsus parvus et tardus.

Aortic stenosis is the narrowing of the aortic valve. It may be caused due to the calcification of the normal aortic valve or the congenital bicuspid valve, and rheumatic heart disease. Narrowing of the aortic valve causes a decreased stroke volume. This results in a weak¬†pulse (Parvus) which rises slowly to a delayed peak (tardus), best appreciated in the carotid arteries.

The clinical features of AS are:

  • Exertional dyspnea:¬†This occurs due to left ventricular (LV) diastolic dysfunction. Raised end-diastolic LV volume and reduced LV compliance lead to increased LV pressure, leading to elevation of pulmonary capillary wedge pressure.¬†
  • Angina pectoris: This occurs due to the¬†combination of the increased O2 needs of hypertrophied myocardium and the reduction of O2 delivery.
  • Syncope: This occurs due to the combination of decreased cardiac output and systemic arterial dilation which lead to a reduction of cerebral perfusion.

As LV systole gets prolonged, the aortic component of S2 may become synchronous with the pulmonary component. There may also be a paradoxical splitting of¬†S2, where the aortic component follows the pulmonary component.¬†The murmur in aortic stenosis is typically an ejection systolic murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space and transmitted to the carotids.

The murmur in AS increases in intensity during squatting. This is due to the¬†increase¬†in preload that leads to increased contractility and increased flow across the aortic valve.

Other options:

Option A: Pulsus alternans is defined as beat-to-beat variability in the amplitude of the pulse. It is seen in patients with severe LV dysfunction.

Option B: Pulsus bisferiens¬†also known as bifid pulse has two systolic peaks. It is seen in patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy. There is a rapid upstroke to the first peak (percussion wave) and a slower rise to the second peak (tidal wave). It is also rarely appreciated in patients with severe aortic regurgitation.

Option C: Pulsus paradoxus is defined as a fall in systolic pressure > 10mmHg with inspiration. It is seen in patients with pericardial tamponade, severe asthma, massive pulmonary embolism and tension pneumothorax.

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect

Inspiration

(↑venous return to right atrium)
  • ↑ intensity of right-sided sounds

Handgrip

(↑afterload )
  • ↑ intensity of MR, AR, and VSD murmurs
  • ↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
  • MVP: delayed onset of click/murmur

Valsalva-Phase II, standing up

(↓ preload)
  • ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
  • ↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur

Rapid squatting

(↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)
  • ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • ↑ intensity of AS, MR, and VSD murmurs
  • MVP: later onset of click/murmur

questions.text: A young man presents with intense pruritus and has painful, red streaks between his fingers and in the groin area. He states that the itchiness is worse at night. Other members of his family also present with similar complaints. A dermoscopy of his skin is shown below. Which of the following can be used for the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a magnified view of a burrowing trail are suggestive of scabies. 5% permethrin cream is used in the management of this patient.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic infestation caused in humans by the Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis. The characteristic symptoms of a scabies infection include intense itching and superficial burrows. 

Burrow is the characteristic lesion of scabies. They present as slightly raised brownish tortuous lesions. It is created by the excavation of the adult mite in the epidermis. In most people, the trails of the burrowing mites are linear in the skin.

Typical locations of lesions are the finger webs, the flexor surfaces of the wrists, the elbows, the axillae, the buttocks and genitalia, and the breasts of women.

The treatment options are the topical application of 5% permethrin cream, 1% lindane lotion, benzyl benzoate, esdepalletrin (bioallethrin), crotamiton, and precipitated sulfur and oral prescriptions like ivermectin.

All family members, even if asymptomatic need to be treated simultaneously for this condition to prevent reinfection and the clothing needs to be disinfected simultaneously.

Other options:

Option B: Oral albendazole is used in the treatment of larva currens and cutaneous larva migrans. They present as pruritic erythematous papules at the site of penetration of the hookworms with an erythematous serpiginous larva track.

The image below shows cutaneous larva migrans:

The image below shows larva currens:

Option D: Topical corticosteroids are used in certain cases of bed bugs. They present as pruritic maculopapular lesions with a visible hemorrhagic punctum in the centre. Three or four lesions may be arranged in a line or a curve pattern which is called breakfast‚Äêlunch‚Äêdinner alignment.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presents with headaches and high blood pressure. On investigation, increased aldosterone levels are seen and a diagnosis of Conn's syndrome is made. Which of the following is least likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia is least likely to be found in this patient with Conn's syndrome. Patients with Conn's syndrome usually have hypokalemia.

Patients with Conn's syndrome have primary hyperaldosteronism which results in a modest increase in plasma sodium, usually less than 4-6 mEq/L over the normal range, hypokalemia (due to increased K+excretion), hypertension (due to slight increase in ECF volume), metabolic alkalosis because increased hydrogen ions are secreted in the urine.

Excess secretion of aldosterone causes only a modest increase in plasma sodium. When sodium gets reabsorbed, water also accompanies it, resulting in plasma sodium remaining fairly normal.

Primary hyperaldosteronism is due to the autonomous overproduction of aldosterone with resultant suppression of RAAS. It can occur due to adrenal hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma. When primary hyperaldosteronism is due to an aldosterone-secreting adenoma, it is called Conn's syndrome. Patients are usually treated with spironolactone followed by surgical removal of adenoma. In patients treated with spironolactone, the adenomas contain eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions called spironolactone bodies.
